question: Question_08_(a)
statement:
Consider the chemical reaction

\[\displaystyle
A + B \rightarrow C + D.\]

Suppose at time \emph{t} = 0 sec the concentration of chemical \emph{A}
is 0.1 mol/L, the concentration of chemical \emph{B} is 0.2 mol/L, and
the concentrations of chemicals \emph{C} and \emph{D} are both 0. For
\emph{t} ≥ 0, let \emph{x(t)} be the concentration of chemical \emph{D}
in mol/L. It can be shown that \emph{x(t)} is the solution to the
initial-value problem

\[\frac{dx}{dt} = k(0.1-x)(0.2-x), \quad x(0)=0,\]

where \emph{k} is a positive constant whole value can be determined by
experiment.

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
(a) Solve the initial-value problem to find \emph{x(t)} explicitly.
\end{description}
sols:
Cross multiplying our equation, we have that

\[\frac{1}{(0.1 - x)(0.2-x)} \, dx = k \, dt\]

Now we integrate. The right hand side integrates to

\[\int k \, dt = kt\]

As for the left hand side, we integrate by partial fractions.

\begin{align*}
\frac{1}{(0.1 - x)(0.2-x)}  &= \frac{A}{(0.1-x)} + \frac{B}{(0.2-x)} \\
&= \frac{A(0.2-x) + B(0.1-x)}{(0.1 - x)(0.2-x)} \\
&= \frac{(-A-B)x + A(0.2) + B(0.1)}{(0.1 - x)(0.2-x)}
\end{align*}

Now we can either compare coefficients or plug in values for \emph{x}. I
will choose to plug in values for \emph{x}. The above tells us that

\[\displaystyle
1 = A(0.2-x) + B(0.1-x)\]

when $x = 0.2$, we have that

\[\displaystyle
1 =  A(0.2-0.2) + B(0.1-0.2) = B(-0.1)\]

and so $B = -10$. When $x = 0.1$, we have

\[\displaystyle
1 =  A(0.2-0.1) + B(0.1-0.1) = A(0.1)\]

and so $A = 10$. Hence, we have

\begin{align*}
\int \frac{1}{(0.1 - x)(0.2-x)} \, dx &= \int \frac{10}{(0.1-x)}\, dx - \int\frac{10}{(0.2-x)}\, dx \\
&= -10\ln|0.1-x| + 10\ln|0.2-x|.
\end{align*}

(technically the above should add a constant but we can include this in
a minute.) Hence

\[\int \frac{1}{(0.1 - x)(0.2-x)} \, dx = \int k \, dt\]

becomes

\[\displaystyle
10\ln|0.2-x| - 10\ln|0.1-x| = kt + C\]

Using the initial condition of $x(0) = 0$, we see that our constant is

\[\displaystyle
10\ln|0.2| - 10\ln|0.1| = C\]

and simplifying, this becomes

\[\displaystyle
C = 10(\ln\tfrac{0.2}{0.1}) = 10\ln(2)\]

Our equation simplifies to

\[\displaystyle
10\ln \left|\frac{0.2-x}{0.1-x} \right| = 10\ln|0.2-x| - 10\ln|0.1-x| = kt +10\ln(2)\]

Exponentiating the far left and the far right hand sides of the above
gives

\[\left|\frac{0.2-x}{0.1-x} \right|^{10}  = 2^{10}e^{kt}\]

Taking the tenth root of both sides yields

\[\left|\frac{0.2-x}{0.1-x} \right|  = 2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}}\]

Removing the absolute values, we have

\[\frac{0.2-x}{0.1-x}  = \pm 2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}}\]

Plugging in the initial condition of $x(0) = 0$, we see that only the
positive value above works. Hence

\[\frac{0.2-x}{0.1-x}  = 2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}}\]

Now, we cross multiply to see that

\[\displaystyle
0.2-x = 2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}}(0.1-x) = 0.2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}} -x(2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}})\]

Bringing the $x$ values to one side gives

\[\displaystyle
x(2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}})-x = 0.2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}} -0.2\]

Lastly, isolating for $x$ gives

\[\displaystyle
x = \frac{0.2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}} -0.2 }{2e^{\tfrac{kt}{10}} - 1}\]

completing the question.
hints:
Start off by cross multiplying. Then integrate (you may want to use
partial fractions to integrate). I hope you ate your Wheaties because
this is a long one...
